law.catch_line: Misrepresenting current or former military status -- Exemptions -- Penalties -- Transfer of fines revenue -- Short title.

text.section:
A person is guilty of misrepresenting current or former military status when he or she, for the purpose of direct or indirect monetary gain, and with intent to defraud, obtain employment, or be elected or appointed to public office, intentionally makes:
A claim, orally, in writing, or by any fraudulent display, that he or she is entitled to wear military awards, military decorations, or military rank;
A claim that he or she served in the United States Armed Forces, a Reserve Component thereof, or the National Guard; or
A claim that he or she served in the military during a wartime era, whether or not there was a declared war, or served in a combat zone, or makes any misrepresentation of actual military service.

Misrepresenting current or former military status is:
A violation of KRS 514.040 if the defendant, by the misrepresentation, obtains money or property; and
If the defendant, by the misrepresentation, obtains a public benefit, a violation of the applicable statute that prohibits obtaining that public benefit and provides a specific penalty.

If a violation of subsection (3) of this section is not involved, the defendant shall be fined an amount not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000) or be imprisoned in the county jail for not more than twelve (12) months, or both.

KRS 431.100 to the contrary notwithstanding, any fine assessed as a penalty for conviction under this section shall be transferred by the circuit clerk and deposited with the veterans program trust fund established by KRS 40.460(2)(b).
This section shall be cited as the Kentucky Stolen Valor Act.
